It's funny, engaging, and honestly pretty scary when the demon shows up.The sub plots are good and entertaining. I know a lot of people said they make the storyline too busy but I loved it.Walter Peck returns as the mayor which is an awesome throwback (esp when someone in the crowd calls him d--less as a reference to what Venkman calls him the first movie). Slimer returns. There's a hunch of random Easter eggs that pop up throughout referencing the previous movies.I love the introduction of the new people- especially Kumail Ali Nanjiani. He plays his part well and brings a goofiness to the story.Honestly I like this one way more than Afterlife and felt it was more like the original movies as far as the mix of comedy and scare. I can't wait to watch it again as soon as it comes to streaming.

title: overun its course
text: When original ideas are cast aside in favour of nostalgia or by the moronic idea that people only want to see what they are familiar with, the gaps are filled with mediocrity. Rusted on fans of the original will enjoy their stroll down memory lane, others not so. There are occasional quips, but the story is flat save for the relationship developing between the younger Spengler and a chess playing ghost. However, the decision to dilute this to a point where not even a kiss is shared counters the important role this character plays in the plot. Otherwise, the plot is paper thin: A new ghost is in town, and the gang defeat it. The suspense on whether they will succeed is non-existent. Mckenna Grace dominates the film with her performance and invests the only discernible emotion present.

title: Why does busting feel so dull now?
text: When me and my girlfriend first met we bonded over our love or films particularly those from the 1980s. Whenever we watch modern movies she has a tendency to still find them entertaining while I complain that things just aren't as good as what they were in the old days. This was certainly the case with Ghostbusters Afterlife which she enjoyed, and has watched multiple times, while i didn't really care for it that much despite a quite good third act.I honestly thought it was going to be the same scenario with Ghostbusters Frozen Empire but it wasn't. We actually agreed on this one! Agreed that we both almost fell asleep!I will always have a tear in my eye watching the original guys suit up whatever the quality of the film. We even get Janine Melnitz in uniform, something I've wanted to see since Ghostbusters 2. The only problem is she's given nothing to do.The original Ghostbusters films were never what you'd call action packed bit there was lots of great gags and investigating and likeable performances that kept you enthralled all the way through them. Even Ghostbusters 2 which ,as an 11 year old kid walking out of the cinema, I knew in my heart wasn't as good as the first film but was still hugely entertaining.Frozen Empire has none of that. The new characters are all devoid of anything resembling a personalty, Pheobe is still OK but the film unfortunately has to think of things for her dull brother to do. Cutting his bits out would've really helped with the pacing.Too many characters and not a lot going on. The villain is barely in it which is a shame as when things eventually get going it starts to look promising but it's all over pretty quickly by that point.I know the original guys are getting old but I still believe that they could carry an entire film by themselves. We laughed at a couple gags and that was thanks to Bill Murray and Dan Akyroyd.I know people say "Haters gonna hate" but I'm no hater when it comes to Ghostbusters, I'm a lifelong fan, but at this point I may have to bail out of this particular franchise with a very heavy heart.

title: Slow paced
text: This film was so slow paced I want to watch a film and be on the edge of my seat alert and hooked on what's happening next.Where as this film felt boring and lack of imaginationI appreciate the hard work of the company that made it.However when the film feels like a choir to watch and your thinking in the cinema I hope it's over soon you can't deny that this film lacks enjoyment.I guess there using a brand to get views.Apparently I need to leave 600 words so I guess the reason I would rate it 4 out of 10 is because they have some good cinematic shots along with some convincing CGI so well done to those who put the hard work in to make the film feel professional.

title: It was awesome!
text: I just saw it today and I love the fact they went back to 1984 with some things. Like the ghost lady in the library from the original. Brought back Walter Peck. Love the new cast members they have now also. Great actors and actresses. They have done a great job with films they have done. I have not been disappointed with any of the ghostbusters films they have done after part 2. Bringing back the 4 original ghostbusters. I know Harald Ramis has passed and I do miss him in the films. RIP Harald! You are missed! I will tell you though they have done a great job with the newest ones bringing a new cast!

title: Unfunny, unimaginative, slow and boring.
text: I watched Ghostbusters Frozen Empire today and I have to say as much as I didn't like Afterlife much this one was even worse. The ending was so small in scale. It all took place in the headquarters and no one would know but then at the end the whole of New York is outside chanting ghostbusters like they'd been watching it all play out.Just a really poorly thought out film that doesn't use any of the older cast much besides Dan. Also it has so many *do you remember this?* scenes and they don't even make sense. Why is slimer just randomly in the loft? Why is the same ghost from the library still there doing the same jump scare? Why are there tiny stay pufts still/again? They're not as funny as the director thinks they are.Kumail Nanjiani very easily stole the show.

title: franchises are the bane of good films
text: This "Ghostbusters Frozen" has everything bad that current new movies can have: a dysfunctional family, weird teenager, awkward young, an incompetent adult as a father, bizarre old people.Some nostalgic items (old car, pistols) and current technology (flying drone, remote control car) are mixed to work together.Lots of speech. They talk too much. Things about quantum physics... pure nonsense! And the Brazilian dubbing is horrible, really awful.The worst of all is that from the beginning of the film ghosts appear, as if we live with them normally, and this takes away all the surprise. But it has a purpose: to sell gifts, dolls, collectibles.

title: Don't answer the call for this forgettable sequel
text: While the original Ghostbusters is a funny and entertaining classic of its time, and "Ghostbusters: Afterlife" had its moments, this sequel is about as forgettable and bland as it gets, and clearly shows that there is unfortunately not too much more to do with this franchise. I only went to see this in theaters because I had a free ticket; otherwise, I would have waited to stream it. While the new cast that started with "Afterlife" (Paul Rudd, Carrie Coon, Finn Wolfhard, and Mckenna Grace) try their best with the material they are given, the movie just simply isn't interesting enough to have much bandwidth.Despite being relatively short at around 110 minutes, the film's pacing is erratic and messy. The first half to two thirds of the movie are quite dull, with relatively little of significant consequence to the plot going on. Yet the film gets to the climactic action very abruptly--and, since it happens so late in the film, fleetingly too. It feels tedious before that climax comes and the film starts feeling rushed, which is a very unusual situation for a big-budget movie to have. The duller first two acts are diluted by some rather uninteresting sub-plots, including one about Mckenna Grace's character befriending a young female ghost. The supporting characters aren't too memorable either, including Kumail Nanjiani's character (which is unfortunate, because he is a talented actor.) The comic relief isn't particularly funny, the action isn't particularly thrilling, and the film just feels rather "been there, done that." Even the appearances of original Ghostbusters doesn't feel too special, since they already came back in "Afterlife." While sporadic moments of the film can be entertaining, there is little else to recommend here, and there's no real reason from a storytelling perspective that this movie exists other than "well, it's another Ghostbusters movie." 4/10.

title: okay-ish movie built on nostalgia
text: If you plan on watching this movie, make sure not to expect too much. It's alright, but not comparable with the first movie, especially in terms of its charm.The movie is really good at connecting to the fans who grew up with the original movie. Especially the return of the old ghost busters and the iconic theme song was pretty well done. But it would be hard to do anything wrong with that.For me, everything else was very mediocre. The storyline felt very slow and when it finally began to be exciting, it was cut short and the movie ended.The movie honestly failed to make me feel connected to the newer characters. The cast wasn't too bad but actors like Finn Wolfhard, who are only known for one big role, are often not a great choice for another franchise movie, because they're always kind of "that one character" (There are many famous exceptions like Margot Robbie or Christian Bale, who can do great performances while not being known for one role). I think a rather unknown actor would've been a better choice, but maybe they just needed to target a certain fan base.Also, the entire storyline between Melody and Fibi kind of felt like it was only there to have the plot make sense.I think the movie is definitely a fun time, especially if you're a fan of the original, but it's mostly built on nostalgia and not too great.

title: Cringe
text: Well, I thought Afterlife was good fun. So I gave this a chance only to discover that even, the 2016 'reboot' was way better than this steaming pile of c***p.The makers of this movie need to realise a movie needs a script. This one for sure didn't have one. All characters were off, jokes (what jokes?) were lame. Basically the whole thing is just a lazy moneygrab. Lazy writing, lazy creature design... both boring as hell.The old main characters are just there for the sake of being there but it's also no fun. The evil character is super boring as well and gets 3 minutes of screentime. It would have been better to leave the franchise alone. Don't waste your precious time on this one.

title: So much potential - too much stupid lines
text: Ghostbusters has so much potential to make awesome moviesJust have to take out all of the horrible attempts at comedy and get rid of actors that just don't fit it. The Mon for example, just doesn't work. The British guy, unnecessary. Bring the old guys and new kids and of course Paul Rudd.Bring together the writers of supernatural and let em do what they do with the new GB gen.All the attempts at humor didn't work at all, they're just gimmicky and lame. I don't think I laughed once watching this!!!! No one cares about the character la or their sexual dynamics, we just wanna see cool ghosts and hero's busting em. It'd even be better if some characters died and weren't in it anymore.

title: Ignore the bad the bad reviews
text: It's not as good as after life, but it's a lot fun. I don't understand all the bad reviews. This movie is exactly what I hoped for. It was both fresh and nostalgic. It was wonderful to see the busters back in NYC. This movie had more of a part 1 feel to it than after life. Though it lacked some of the emotion. Great to see familiar faces back. The new cast is very entertaining. Paul Rudd is hilarious as usual. I feel like there was a lot of audiences waiting to put down this movie. Ghostbusters has always been about the little scares and the laughs. Frozen Empire delivered on both accounts! Give it a shot.

title: Mediocre
text: Gone is the charm and comedy of the original Ghostbusters. This one doesn't even stand up to the first reboot from this cast. Paul Rudd playing exactly the same character as he does in the Antman movies is just tiresome. This film lacks humour, lacks a decent story, and sadly lacks much in the way of action, which for a film just shy of two hours makes for a painfully boring movie.Like so many movie franchise continuations today, this is a case of the movie studios flogging a dead horse, or milking a barren cow. I actually despair that some people actually enjoy this heavily flawed movie. Hopefully no more.

title: Loved it!
text: This was a fun and entertaining movie. They added more comedy to this one than Afterlife. It kind of reminds me of how the first two movies were. Afterlife was more serious just like the original first movie, and then Frozen Empire had way more comedy just like Ghostbusters 2. I have no complaints and will be going back to the theater to watch it again. I've veen a Ghostbusters fan since I saw the first movie around 35 years ago and I'm very happy with this movie. It definitely earned its place in the franchise and seeing some new old faces made it even more nostalgic. I hope they make another one!

title: Ghostbustin' makes me feel sad
text: The movie ends after a tortuous journey of making you think it's going to get going on a awful short set piece that makes a mockery of everything that can before it.I don't know how to set your expectations any lower than that.Some reviews mention great fan service, they are wrong. It's contrived.Afterlife made a half decent attempt of being the franchise back to life, but this simply trashes all the positive steps it made.You get to see some great old characters come back and do nothing.You get to see the new characters perform pointless roles in a completely under fleshed storyline, that I'm struggling to find a comparable movie where talent is so terribly wasted.It's not even worth watching to see how poor it is.

title: Another good funny Ghostbusters Movie.
text: Don't listen to the critics, haters and trolls of bad reviews. The movie is fun, funny and just plain good. It has the spirt of the original. The whole cast is great, wonderful seeing the original cast with the new. Great seeing ecto 1 fixed and cleaned and ready for action. Love hearing the siren and seeing the blue lights. Cool new gadgets with the wonderful proton paks. It's definitely another good Ghostbusters movie. The film has fresh ideas with staying with the tried and true of Ghostbusters. Overall everbody should just go see it and make up their own minds if they like it or not. Just go see it.

title: Jurassic world dominion: ghostbusters edition
text: This movie went wrong in so many ways but it had a few redeeming qualities. Paul rudd was pretty funny and was easily the best character in yhe whole film. And the main ice dude, although is only in it for like 20 mins was pretty chilling and actually made for a cool villian.On the downside this movie tries to push a bunch of characters in your face to distract you from it's poor writing but it does not work. Apart from Paul rudd this movie is ridiculously unfunny. Also the characters feel like they got a serious downgrade from the first one. Giving mckenna grace the main role was a good idea in theory. But in this one her character felt really wooden and borderline emotionless for the whole film. 3/10.

title: Old School Fun Movie
text: Anyone giving this anything less than a positive review needs to take a few deep breaths and step away from their phone/tablet/pc etc. This is a FUN movie! It's not meant to be Shakespeare. There are plenty of genuinely funny bits in this, lots of great action sequences and plenty of nostalgia for old school Ghostbusters fans.Where the last movie was more of an emotional roller coaster ride this one is FUN! With all that's going on in the world right now we need more fun movies.Ignore the negative reviews. If you're a fan of the original movie (and perhaps the cartoon series) you'll love this.

title: What a Bust
text: Horrible writing mixed with actors who were promised better = this garbage. I truly think you are better off not seeing this hot (frozen) wasteland of a film. Paul Ruddy couldn't even save this one. The trailers looked promising and like you actually were going to get to see some busting of ghost action! This is false . This is 100% false.They even attempted to do some nostalgia bait, using old effects on some of the ghosts. But it just didn't fit in because the other ghosts were CGI so it was confusing that they all looked so different.Something strange in your neighborhood it happens to be showing at your local cinema, don't show up and watch it. It's hot doo doo garbage.

title: It could be way better!
text: Lacked any interest, while it got very boring. So many indifferent scenes, with nothing interesting happening.. The super ghost fell within minutes!! Why? Where is the thrill in it? Where are the new scary ghosts? It seems that was handled by amateurs.. I watched some attempts to repeat the old movies scenarios, but they weren't enough to save it. I begin to believe that they need to stop making these sequels. Find someone that can unleash the true potential of the legend, and it will be a global success!I grew with the first two movies. I have watched them countless times! They never get old!So sad the two first epic movies were to create the legend, but the three latter to destroy it. Deeply disappointed.

title: A mess
text: Just finished watching. The film is all over the place so it's difficult to know where to begin, so I'll break it down into positives and negatives.Positives - The villain is cool, Zedmore gets some screen time, some nice nods to the original, CGI is ok, last part of the movie is fairly interesting.Negatives - No ghosts apart from the beginning and ending, incoherent story, too much family drama, awful characters (Lucky, the whole Spengler family, stupid fire master, the blue ghost). Janine actually does nothing even though she gets suited up.Overall, so frustrating to watch because if they cut all the boring stuff it would've been pretty good.

title: Member?!?!
text: Huh do ya?? You remember this character? You remember that character? You remember this this that happened in the better movie?? That's all this flick is.And it couldn't be any less funny if it tried.. it's honestly kinda depressing. The only slightly good character is Ray.. everyone else is either annoying as hell, cringe, or moody to the point of aggravation.None of the jokes land at all. The plot is the most predictable thing imaginable. Everyone is a Ghostbuster now for some reason. Like EVERYONE.It feels more like a marvel movie than an actual Ghostbusters movie.. I feel like this one and the last film just coast by solely on member berries. There's literally nothing else of value here.2 points for a decent production I guess...

title: I'm deeply cynical about any film that has such an aggressive promo campaign,
text: Rubbish. Pointless. A shameless cash grab upon the die hard fans of the original.Let's be honest - only the first, original ghostbusters is ANY good. Ramis must be spinning in his grave at what these chancers have done to his legacy.People need to start being more critically minded because the exact same pattern (relentless instagram adverts) occurred with the absolute DUDS that were Frosted and If. Stop wasting your money on something they're barraging you with. I only heard about late night with the devil through word of mouth and that's the best new film I've seen in over a decade.Don't waste your time or your money on this absolute tripe.

title: Really wanted to like this one but it's a very unnecessary sequel
text:
For starters it felt like there was a lot of footage cut from what we saw from the trailers and tv spots. I think with an extended cut, this would make the the film benefit a lot more with its newly added characters and the pacing of how it flows with the writing and story.But even with hopes of that happening, that probably wouldn't even save this installment to the franchise as being a worthy addition.There's too much nostalgia bait thrown in this that feels not very well worthy to be included unless absolutely necessary if it is executed right.Phoebe, sad to say it, also had wasted character development which is a shame since she was one of the best things in Afterlife serving as one of the main selling point attractions as she was the daughter of Egon Spengler.And the rest of the cast was fine, especially the OG CAST I guess,
but they felt heavily underutilized and rushed in a way that you don't even bother to try and resonate with them or have a care.There's also some really weird misdirection in this movie too that made me facepalm or say "Is this really necessary?" like ughh,
you feel like couldn't the filmmakers have done something better?At this point it's felt that they are running out of ideas to try and make the plot of the movie plausible or watchable.But yeah....very....meh...I'm sorry, but the busting in Frozen Empire doesn't make you feel good as a long time fan or to a normal movie goer or to the audience in general.

title: Ghostbusters: Waste Of Time
text: After Ghostbusters: Afterlife, which was moderately entertaining and unpretentious, I thought this would be at least as entertaining, but unfortunately it's not even close.The only good thing about this movie is the old cast, Dan Aykroyd, Ernie Hudson and Bill Murray, the rest is a disaster.The script is clumsy, and at the same time the writers did not resist the desire to "teach" the viewer, which automatically causes a counter-effect and destroys any chance of entertainment.Fortunately, when I saw certain actors in the cast, I decided that I would not go to the cinema to see this movie, but would wait until I could watch it for free. Good decision, because if I had gone to the cinema, I would have wasted both time and money, this way I only wasted time. A time I will never get back.The whole movie is generic, the script is unimaginative, the jokes are dull and unfunny, and the actors look bored.Even the old team can't save this disaster, because the script is just bad.It's a shame, the movie had potential, but the writers ruined it.

title: Why can't the bad guy ever win!
text: I paid to see this. I paid to see this? Yes, it's my fault. Needless action sequences that don't add to any of the story. Was Marvel involved in this because it sure borrowed from the same tired story lines. This is the worst movie I have seen this year. I was hoping that Mr Horney was going to put an end to all of the Ghostbusters but that never happened. The marshmallow men are just idiotic. Paul Rudd is just not funny anymore, he's worn out his welcome. A lot of this movie was just forced and not funny. Unnecessary storylines that don't add anything to the movie. Suck this one up with a vacuum cleaner, it's a real Ghostbuster hairball.

title: Awesome movie
text: I really enjoyed this movie. Ghostbusters 1 &2 are cult classics for me. Ghostbusters afterlife was a shocking and very awesome addition to the franchise and now Frozen Empire is another perfect addition. Along with very fun connections to the originals it adds more fun and understanding to the ghost universe. I also enjoyed the effects of this movie. I find most movies these days overuse cgi and creates an extremely fake realm, where this movie really gets the effects right. The main villain looks straight out of a nightmare in the best way possible the found a way to give an extremely life like appearance to an obviously fake character. Paul Rudd is a great addition to the franchise as well. 20/10 for me.

title: Plot hole city.. its just ok
text: Saw this in theaters on a date, it was just ok. He liked it more than I did, but we both agreed the last one was better. It picks up right where the last one left off, so if you havent seen that youre going to be lost right out of the gate. Not that it honestly matters much, the movie is nothing but plot holes. The plot holes section for this movie should be 10 pages long..but only film buffs actually care about plot holes!Heres the movie in a nutshell: The granddaughter phoebe acts like a complete brat and gets everyone in trouble over and over...then they trust her again for literally no reason over and over. Dont expect it to tie itself together and like she redeems herself or something. Nope, they just hand the brat the working only weapon after she caused all the problems... and let her walk off with it, no explanation...Its baffling to watch so hopefully youre only there for the cameos and cute ghosts. I get that bad parenting is a thing lots of people experience, but dang this mom is worse than the mom from Home Alone!

title: Even Nostalgia has an expiration date...
text: You didn't have to summon the ghost of Nostradamus to be able and predict that the successful "Ghostbusters: Afterlife" would quickly lead to another sequel, and maybe even a completely new series. Don't get me wrong, I really enjoyed that 2021 comeback film, but it was basically everything that Hollywood loves the most: big financial profit through minimal creative effort. Everybody wanted to see the new generation of ghostbusters team up with the original members. Everybody loves nostalgia; - including me.But the second "legacy sequel" - apparently that's what they call this type of films - already painfully makes clear that even nostalgia has an expiration date. "Frozen Empire" simply isn't very good. The plot blindly follows the structure of all the previous films, and popular gimmicks/fixed values are dragged in purely for nostalgia, but they aren't adding any value (like the Slimer-creature, the little marshmallow-men, and even Bill Murray himself).Like in the old days, Ghostbusters proves that people - and inhabitants of New York in particular - are ungrateful hypocrites suffering from continuous memory loss. Despite having saved the city three times already, the Ghostbusters are only blamed for reckless behavior and receive lawsuits for destroying half of the city whenever they go out to bust a ghost or creature. The familiar looking mayor even wants to shut them down permanently. Meanwhile, a new and almighty evil creature manifests itself through an ancient artifact and patiently awaits the right time to turn NY into the titular frozen empire. Its name is Garraka, and this malignant ice deity is by far the biggest reason to seek out the new "Ghostbusters" movie, as it's imposing and genuinely uncanny.It certainly isn't a punishment to watch this new entry in the 40-year-old franchise. Paul Rudd is always fun to watch, the sub plot about two melancholic teen girls - one alive and one dead - is endearing, Kumail Nanjiani has a few funny lines, and it was nice to see Dan Aykroyd in a significant role again. In the end and rationally analyzed, though, it's an unmemorable Sci-Fi/action flick of which you realize you wouldn't bother to go to the cinema for if it hadn't the "Ghostbusters" label on it.

title: A film for true Ghostbusters fans
text: I love the Ghostbusters and so far I'm a fan of the new crew. To me, this movie is a heartfelt ode to the franchise's enduring legacy, made all the more special by the return of the original Ghostbusters actors in their iconic uniforms. As a long-time fan, seeing Bill Murray, Dan Aykroyd, Ernie Hudson don their proton packs once again brought an overwhelming sense of nostalgia and joy.Their presence on screen not only rekindled cherished memories from my youth but also served as a powerful reminder of the timeless magic that made the original films so beloved.Watching them effortlessly slip back into their roles with the same wit, charm, and comradery was an absolute delight. It's a testament to the enduring appeal of the Ghostbusters universe and a treat for fans old and new to witness these legendary actors back in action, capturing the essence of what made the franchise so special in the first place.

title: They don't understand what made the original great
text: While better than the mopey, depressing Afterlife, Ghostbusters: Frozen Generic Title once again baffles by screwing up what should be an easy concept.Ghostbusters was not about busting ghosts. It wasn't about Gozer. It was about 3 guys starting a ridiculous business. There was the science guy, the spiritualist / occultist / historian, and the opportunist / con man Venkman. Nobody believed in them, but we as the audience knew they were right.Frozen Empire wisely does away with the depressed tone of the previous movie but still fails to get the most important thing right: motivation. Why are they in New York? Why are they hunting ghosts? It was barely explained in the last movie, and it's even less plausible here. None of them except Phoebe Spengler seem to want to hunt ghosts.Beyond that, the movie suffers from character overload. They have the 6 new characters, the 3 surviving original Ghostbusters, Janine Melnitz, the Pakistani guy, the tech guy employed by Winston...Most of the new adult characters are good. Nadeem Razmaadi is highly enjoyable in his scenes, and Dan Aykroyd is always enjoyable. He's still got his heart in it, and it shows, whereas Bill Murray is in the film for about 30 seconds...which isn't much more than most Characters. Finn Wolfhard is more or less forgotten halfway through the movie and then shows up again at the end. He has no character arc. Same for his girlfriend from the last movie and the Asian podcaster kid. Both feel tacked on.Paul Rudd and Carrie Coon's characters barely have anything to do and feel lost in the plot, because they don't have the intelligence to understand any of the Ghost tech.This is a central flaw of the film. In the original, the central characters knew what they were doing. Here, only the kids seem to understand the technology, but it never works. The "genius kid" trope is annoying. Kids in sci fi comedies work best if they employ creative thinking or common sense, much like Marty McFly in Back to the Future. Imagine that film of Marty was the genuis and Doc Brown was the bumbling idiot along for the ride. It wouldn't have worked.Ideally the new Ghostbusters movies would have gone like this:The old Ghostbusters try to build a new team to carry on their legacy - turning it into another business comedy, by showing the pitfalls and frustrations of passing on the torch. They could have been taken advantage of by young people not believing them and just trying to make money or frustrated by Gen Z's lack of work ethic. Or clashed with other eccentric characters who may have the smarts but not the discipline - or who have the motivation, but not the smarts. This could have led to interesting character dynamics in the style of the original.The most interesting aspect of Frozen Empire is Phoebe's lesbian ghost romance. Their story arc was actually interesting, and I wanted to see where it would go.The whole firecasting subplot was another misfire. The original wisely had science beat the occult. They didn't need a magical dagger or other macguffin to beat Gozer. Science beat superstition. Here, they introduce a character with magical powers, throwing that theme out of the window.At least the movie is briskly paced and barely gives you time to think about how stupid it is. Some of the skits are charming, and there are enough jokes to keep you entertained over its runtime. There are also no obnoxious identity politics or lectures.As a generic fantasy movie, it's fine. As a sequel to one of the greatest comedy films of all time, it falls flat. But it's leagues better than Afterlife.

title: There is a hipster chess playing ghost
text: First half is just one big exposition dump. The rest is predictable. So predictable that I guessed the end of almost every scene as soon as it started and knew what was coming next. Acting is awful. Tension is non-existent. Effects were done on a Commodore 64. Script was written on used toilet paper which was recycled from Glastonbury music festival. That one where it rained non-stop and the sewage overflowed and mingled with all the mud and people's sweat and grime from four days rolling in muck after which the screenwriter who was probably on duty collecting rubbish picked up a sodden piece of crap encrusted tissue and wrote this movie in -30 seconds. Absolute crap.

title: Did'nt like it
text: Ok, I went to see this yesterday. Have to say my wife loved it myself not so much. I liked Afterlife better than this. This latest version of Ghostbusters didn't make much sense to me. One of the things that I noticed in this movie was that the main bad character a demon that freezes the whole of New York only appears towards the ending part of the movie he's hardly in it. The rest of this movie focuses too much on the teen angst angle of things such as a pointless relationship between the daughter and a ghost which to me seemed bordering on the gay aspect of things that didn't fit in with this movie at all too many different subplots and unnecessary characters. Plus there was hardly any humor it wasn't funny not like the original Ghostbusters. Give this one a miss.

title: Very entertaining!
text: I went in with mixed expectations given some low reviews but it was great! Entertaining the whole time and lots of good cameos. A great addition to the Ghostbusters franchise.Lots of little Easter eggs (I think that's what they're called) like when someone mentioned 'gilded age' and that is currently Carrie Coon's hit HBO show. I saw lots of subtle and not so subtle 80s references. I think I spotted the Golden Girls sofa in the firehouse break room? And Kumail Nanjiani's hair reminded me of George Michael.Good family movie, lots of comedic moments and paid homage to the original movie. Only complaint is will this franchise ever play Bobby Brown's 'On Our Own'in one of the sequels?!

title: They forgot to have fun.
text: I think the viewing audience has had their fill of 'member berries'(thank you South Park). It is about time that ridiculous has a comeback. The first movie was great(original NOT afterlife) not only because it was funny, but also because it never took itself seriously(So much talent as well). As soon as I saw the normal looking ghost in Frozen Empire, I got a chill going down my spine, not in a good way. It was dread, the feeling was dread.The jokes were stale, the action was boring, they used Winston as a token rather than a character (His importance was always undervalued, this movie drove it home in a way that felt a little off).Oh and then that part where Phoebe helps Melody, was anyone else reminded of The Real Ghostbusters?(That show is probably the only tie-in that actually tried to honor the original). In fact most of Frozen Empire plays out like bad episodes from the cartoon.Hollywood needs to stop forcing agendas on the audience and just let us enjoy a movie.

title: Disappointing and I really wanted to like it
text: I saw the original on its cinematic release back in 1984 when I was 14 years of age. I went to see it four times on consecutive weekends. I really wanted to like this new film and took my thirteen year old son with his friend. The fact that we all found it dull and not too many jokes says it all. The baddie doesn't even get much screen time and the movie never gets going. Story line is really basic and it feels like I am watching a steady pulse on the screen right through the movie. Not a flatline, but the pulse is just laboured. Too many actors which is a shame as they are all wasted. These films have great potential for amazing story lines but this is just a by the numbers retread. Very sad.

title: Boring made no sense
text: Ghostbusters fell flat on every level. It failed to deliver any excitement, dragging on with a lackluster plot that seemed to go nowhere. Character development was non-existent, leaving the audience disconnected and uninvested in the fate of the characters. Instead of offering fresh perspectives, the film shamelessly relied on nostalgia, desperately clinging to the success of its 80s predecessors. The choice of actors did little to elevate the material, as their performances felt uninspired and forgettable. Save your money and skip this sad attempt to resurrect a franchise that should have been left in the past."

title: Ghostbusters never fails to entertain
text: What's all the negativity about. Critics are the definition of BS. I really don't get the hate and unnderating. It's overly misunderstood. Why can no one accept a good film these days. Nitpick all you want but me and my entire family are massive Ghostbusters fans and it's just a bouncy, vibrant, playful movie to watch. It just captures that Ghostbusters vibe. It's not a clone of Afterlife, its original and atmospheric. The cinematography is great.Cheesy and surprisingly high on the scares.End was a bit anticlimactic and the main villain didn't get enough screen time. I think they were too focused on lore which is interesting but complex adding a good few more characters than needed. Great movie!

title: Decent start, decent ending, 100% poor writing in between
text: As the movie began, I enjoyed the opening. I then predicted that there would be at least 30 minutes of absolutely nothing happening. My daughter would not take the bet. I won the bet at least three times over. I guess they spent all of their CGI budget on the last 20 minutes. That wasn't too bad. I want my $10 back.My teenage daughter liked it though. Unlike me, she didn't find the logical inconsistencies of the plot to be frustrating, maddening, and inane.I enjoyed Afterlife. I thought it was decently written.This reminded me of a plot for a 30-minute Ghostbusters cartoon from the 1990s or 1980s. Very thin on character development and a little bit of action. To be fair, a Ghostbusters cartoon would have more action than this movie.

title: stop hiring Patton Oswald
text: This movie was going fine, a little meh but still watchable until Patton Oswald enters. He's a perv and does skits with Sarah Silverman where he drives around in a van watching kids. Everyone knows there's a tight knit group of friends who visit special islands to touch kids and Sarah, Kimmel and this guy are all guilty. Stop hiring them all.The movie itself although stale and not exciting seems to be made only to keep the franchise going. Meshing Egons family with the original cast seemed like a good idea but this is just a little boring.Paul Rudd is the only redeeming role trying to find his stepdad role instead of teacher but there's still no chemistry between he and Carrie from The Guilded Age. He didn't take it for the script.

title: A good solid movie, with a few flaws, but nothing too bad
text: If you're old like me you may remember seeing ghostbuster in the 80's.This film me and my lad went to see the other night, and I must say I really enjoyed it, however there were a few bits that dragged a little, but nothing too much for me. Acting, brilliant wonderful, always good to see the old starts back together, however there in lies the problem.At one point in the film, they are all suited and booted, and ready to bust and there was just too many ghost buster on the screen, you didn't know who to watch. I under stand why they did it, and if this is a hand over movies, I understand that and now it makes sense.I feel this would be a good point for the original guys to take a step back, and be seen now and then, going forward, and I think you can see that in one aspect of the movie.The ghost are great, and it was great to see slimer again!And a nod to the original film as well, you know it when you see it!Over all a solid movie, go and enjoy, after all 'bustin' makes me feel good!"

title: Lacklustre and mostly boring!
text: Expectations were high following my enjoyment of afterlife and seeing in the trailer that the old crew were back.Frozen Empire took itself too seriously, it lacked the humour and the Ghostbusters vibe that made the franchise a hit in the first place. The fan service moments were the only thing that saved it from being completely awful!Best moment by far comes at the end when the original music kicks in and the Ghostbusters ride off to do some Ghostbusting. Should have had more of that in the movie rather than just ambling through a simplistic and weak plot to a mediocre ending.There were some good performances and a couple of laughs, but overall it was just dull!3/10.

title: It had fun parts
text: Ok... First off do you really expect me to believe that moron has been Mayor for 40 yrs? So stupid, also the foreshadowing in this movie is painfully obvious and how is it a ghost gets to hang on to a real matchbook for how long and it vanishes with her? Also it's basically Ghostbusters 2 with some family drama... I could watch afterlife over and over but this had to have been written by someone with a head injury... It was pretty bad but for nostalgia, Paul Rudd and the original cast it gets 4 stars. It could have been an epic movie but instead we got this box of disparity....................

title: Great movie!
text: Is my top pick movie for 2024 so far.I love how each of the character were so amazing, each the graphics were also amazing and cool, the plot was good.Awesome!Truly Entertaining!Lots of fun, chuckles, and giggles.A barrel of monkeys!A Family Friendly Paranormal Festival!Awesome!Truly Entertaining!Lots of fun, chuckles, and giggles.A barrel of monkeys!A Family Friendly Paranormal Festival!Awesome!Truly Entertaining!Lots of fun, chuckles, and giggles.A barrel of monkeys!A Family Friendly Paranormal Festival!Awesome!Truly Entertaining!Lots of fun, chuckles, and giggles.A barrel of monkeys!A Family Friendly Paranormal Festival!

title: I didn't care for it
text: Unpopular opinion, but the Ghostbusters franchise as a whole is just a waste of time. And yes, that includes the original which I still think is an unenjoyably cheap trash film. Saying all that, I still watched the new one, because I've watched four of these already so why not a fifth, and yea, it's about as pointless as I thought it would be.It's not that the movie is bad or poorly written or unfunny, no, it's just so generic and forgettable. Nothing about this movie stands out and nothing about this movie is worth talking about. It seems unmotivated to be anything worth caring about and exists solely to milk some nostalgia money. I don't know, I dislike the franchise anyway, so why listen to me huh?

title: Too much bull.
text: The reason the bull and it's way too long. They should have gotten more minerals form the be so that they can update the storage. I am talking about the kids. And there should not be any politics in the movie. And too long and too boring. It's needs a little bit more action but not too much like godzilla x the new empire. There should be no government in the movies it's just ruins the movie. And the end of the movie does not make any sense they should have upgraded the bag so that they can trap the evil God form the be it world make it easier and more in fact they should have upgraded all of them.

title: This is an impeccable follow-up to Afterlife and a wonderfully refreshing story
text: So I am a massive Ghostbusters nerd, and when I saw the mixed reviews for Frozen Empire I was worried to say the least. Having seen the film I can safely say my fears were alleviated, I had an absolute blast watching it. Without delving into any spoilers, the film was an incredibly written love letter to the franchise taken directly out of the cartoon from the '80's. All of the plot points were well seeded, the villain is incredibly menacing, it has enough identity to separate it from the other films, and the characters were interesting to explore. The humour was also a highlight. While it sometimes felt a little SNL-esc, the use of worldbuilding within the humour was fun to see and it didn't fail to get a laugh out of me. If I were to point to any issues, I would say the pacing was a little slow with a large emphasis on lore. As a massive nerd my attention was fixated on the screen, however I can understand how it might get boring for some people. That, and the villain was, in the last few scenes, a little underwhelming. I would have liked to see some more chaos shots to an '80's song akin to the originals to show the impact of the villain. He was well built up but sadly fell a little flat towards the end. Overall I would give it a 9/10, excellent watch and a worthy continuation of the franchise.

title: A triangulation of attempted sorrow
text: I have seen this in a dream, where the waking mind has suffered greatly on account of what people suspiciously refer to as "trolls". Although these trolls, and the way they are branded in this movie, are held at arms length, there is a Woman (of the dunes, as prepared by the greatness of Austrian philosophy!) seeking her true offering, her folding into herself a fascinating spectacle. I have never seen any of these trolls, hardly a point to be made. Nonetheless, a troll subjectifies and transcends (again this Austrian philosophy!) the objects of desire, the frail mist of a broken vessel. Did they actually drive the car, one wonders? Leave these questions to the plane of methaporical investigations, these are not words for mortal Men. A man cries, does he not? A woman suffers, does she not? Alas, the triangulation is somewhat complete.

title: A fun visual ride, but very little else of any substance
text: STAR RATING: ***** Brilliant **** Very Good *** Okay ** Poor * AwfulThe new Ghostbusters team, headed by partners Gary (Paul Rudd) and Callie (Carrie Coon), along with Callie's kids, Trevor (Finn Wolfhard) and Phoebe (McKenna Grace) tackle some supernatural forces terrorising New York City, causing a bit of damage in the process, and raising the ire of new mayor Walter Peck (William Atherton), with Phoebe drawing particular scorn. However, original Ghostbuster Ray Stantz (Dan Ackroyd) may hold the key to regaining everyone's affection for them, when a mysterious orb in his possession unleashes the spirit of Gorocca, an ancient God with the power to plunge the city into a deep freeze.Following 2021's Ghostbusters: Afterlife, writer/director Gil Kenan brings the franchise back to the big screen, forty years after the iconic original film was released, and determined to keep the series rolling. With the current stars and the original actors meeting at a crossroads, it's a weird reflection of how far the series has come, and where it may be stuck. With all the original stars crammed in together with the new performers, it's an overstuffed egg resulting in too many characters to keep up with, and clearly still too clingy to its original source material.As a big screen, visual spectacle, it's still an impressive, immersive experience, the kind of thing 3D was created for, and on this front could provide a fun day out for all the family. The special effects, then, make it a sort of fun ride. But of course, they can't compensate for a weak, flat plot, and unfunny, forced humour, that the original managed so effortlessly. While original stars Ackroyd and Ernie Hudson as Winston Zeddemore, who's now an entrepreneur, seem to embrace the whole thing as wildly as they can, strangely its original rivals Murray and Atherton who seem more reluctant, with Atherton's arsey, bureaucratic Peck now more awkwardly inserted into scenes, while Murray shows up for roughly half an hour towards the end. This uneven distribution of faith in the project between the stars is one of the many disconcerting things about the whole thing.If you're in an especially undemanding mood, it does provide a decent, flashy fun ride, but there's very little beneath the surface beyond a commercial interest in keeping the franchise going, and letting the quality take a backslide. **

title: What a dog!
text: Really poor movie. Not really engaging and I only laughed twice (near the end of the movie). Not sure why Bill Murray is even in this movie - if he made more than a few thousand dollars for his appearance, he was overpaid. Only has about 10 lines, none of which are meaningful.There is no character development, and the new mom & dad (of the new Ghostbusters) have no real personalities of their own, especially the mother.Add to this all the inconsistencies in the plot. The way certain problems are remedied have no real or logical explanations, even in the context of a movie that demands that you suspend disbelief.I thought Ghostbusters 2 was bad, but this one is far worse. I have it a 3 because it wasn't as horrible as bottom-of-the-barrel movies like American Anthem, Son of Blob or The Legend of Boggy Creek. Don't waste your time on this one.

title: Fun and exciting sequel that delivers to fan service and newcomers.
text: 4 out of 5 stars.Ghostbusters: Frozen Empire is a good supernatural comedy film which i found to be very entertaining and fun. Better than Afterlife. Especially with a faster pacing. The film continues with the new cast from the previous film. A new young ghostbusters team lead by Paul Rudd and the young adults. Still has that fun humor which is entertaining. The action sequences are entertaining. The visual effects are also good. The cast did a great job. Mckenna Grace more on the spotlight as she is growing up and conflicted with being part of the team and growing up and finding herself. The original cast are also back and a lot of fun.The new faces may have trouble finding the spotlight in this film with one character being important that can help stop the main evil entity villain with his firepower. And a ghost that becomes friends with Mckenna Graces character. The script kept those minor characters thin.The film is better paced. Fun humor. More action. And a bigger threat that makes this sequel worth watching.

title: The critics were right.
text: I sat through this movie for what seemed like an eternity, with my two kids and half a dozen other patrons (the rest had presumably done their homework and avoided the unnecessary expense).It starts off promisingly with an interesting historical context and a good old chase through present-day Manhattan. Then, the characters pile up, action draws to a close and we're doled out a frankly dumb and patronising parenting sub-plot, within not much of a plot. Whatever happened to escapism in cinema? Paul Rudd is supremely irritating as the kooky everyman, Carrie Coon uncharismatic and an ensemble of work-in-progress teen actors are each vying for attention like they're in a school play. Each dialed-in witticism sinks without trace. Dan Ackroyd is probably the most compelling force in the movie, but you can't rely on one seasoned actor to do the heavy lifting. The 2016 reboot had far more swagger and intelligence than this.Finale was meh and effects-wise, seemed like the budget had been exhausted by the ridiculously extended payroll.Nope. This was a dud I'm afraid.

title: The new Ghostbusters leaves you as a viewer somewhat out in the cold due to the many messy storylines.
text: Ghostbusters: Frozen Empire is the sequel to Ghostbusters: Afterlife. A film that tried to breathe new life into the film series for old fans of the film series, but also for new fans of this generation. This new film is directed, written and produced in part by Gil Kenan, director of City of Ember and the 2015 Poltergeist remake.The Spengler family has moved to the New York firehouse where the original Ghostbusters team had their secret research lab.The discovery of an ancient artifact unleashes an evil force that deceives New York and the rest of the world with a new ice age. To prevent this, the new Ghostbusters must team up with the old members of the original team.The director and writer of the previous Ghostbusters film Jason Reitman has stepped down as co-writer and producer for this sequel. Jason remains the son of Ivan Reitman, who was the mastermind behind the original Ghostbusters film series.By filling this new film with the old and new characters and in addition to some references from the old films, they have made this film a bit too full. This can sometimes make the film seem a bit messy or long-winded. Most of the characters in this film also have their own storyline, but because of all these different storylines it sometimes remains difficult or uninteresting to follow them all exactly.The best moments in this new film are when it comes to Mckenna Grace and Dan Aykroyd's characters, as they really do more research into the threat of the ice demon. The other characters are more concerned with their own things, but these are more separated from the real story of the film until the end. As a result, it takes a while before the real threat of the ice demon really begins.

title: Disappointing!
text: I finally got around to watching the latest Ghostbusters tonight. And I have to say that I'm disappointed.I enjoyed seeing the original (surviving) members reunited. That was really nice. But the script wasn't very good. The story just wasn't there for a feature film. We had to go through the whole 'Ghostbusters being arrested' thing. Even though they had saved the city multiple times before. The writing was just disappointing.If it wouldn't have been for the old cast, I would have rated it a two or three.I truly hope this is the last Ghostbusters movie. Two of the last three were dogs. Anyways, it was nice seeing the old cast one last time.

title: Love it
text: Ghostbusters 2024 delivers a fresh and exciting take on the beloved franchise, blending nostalgia with modern storytelling. The film boasts impressive visual effects, a talented ensemble cast, and witty humor that will leave audiences entertained from start to finish. With its perfect balance of homage to the original and innovative new elements, Ghostbusters 2024 successfully captures the essence of what made the original film a classic while carving out its own identity. A must-watch for fans old and new alike!Additionally, the film introduces captivating new characters and expands the Ghostbusters universe, ensuring a thrilling ride for all.LOVE IT.

title: Annoying Kids
text: This movie gave me the "Wesley Crusher" effect. There are a bunch of kids, and you start to hate them because they are all supposed to be super smart and great. In the 21st century, you get them in all colors, so you do not face just one annoying kid but many of them.The frustration builds as these kids, who are clearly not ready for it, are given access to advanced technology. They're a mix of researchers and ghostbusters, a combination that only adds to the irritation.The whole movie, you hope that these annoying characters will eventually be killed off, but you know exactly what story writing wants: that everyone - young and old works - together to fight the evil.

title: "I am a God"
text: Ghostbusters: Frozen Empire is disappointing, I know why the legacy characters were in the movie, unfortunately it was for the wrong reasons. Cuz it's for ticket sales and not story related, specially Bill Murray.What that does is make the good characters established in Afterlife mostly background characters. A good example of this is Finn Wolfhard is just there to say he's old now, and for a side quest, if you take him out, the movie is exactly the same. Which is a shame, cuz they set something up and just forgot it completely, McKenna Grace is good, but her character isn't very likeable.Script was weak, not interesting, not even funny, the "villain" is bland story wise, character wise and even visually. There are some good things, Kumail Nanjiani is great here, Paul Rudd as well.The ending tried to be heartfelt, but because I was not invested in the character and their relationships, they didn't hit much. It's a shame, Afterlife was really fun and enjoyable. This felt like cash grab.

title: A really entertaining sequel
text: Go to theaters, buy some popcorn and a drink, sit down and enjoy yourself because that is what Ghostbusters Frozen Empire is, a fun and entertaining ride. If you are expecting a Christopher Nolan or a Martin Scorsese's film then you are in the wrong path, this movie aims mainly to fans, but that can also be enjoyed by newcomers. Some bad reviews are really unfair and quite exagerated, it's like if almost they were written to keep people from watching the film in theaters, but if you are tired of listening to paid critics and want to have a fun time then give it a shot, it's really worth it, I know for sure I'll watch it again sometime next week.

title: So bad it redefines "bad"
text: The original story had something for both kids and adults.That's how you can actually enjoy going to the movies with your kids.THIS redirection of the franchise drives a final nail into its coffin.Instead of building on a decidedly interesting universe, the screenplayers have reduced it to a stumbling domino of barely related events that doesn't even try to handle suspension of disbelief.It's a kid movie, a kid movie only, with no subtelty and zero interest for adults.I have not been able to watch it to the end.Do i recommend it?If you ABSOLUTELY need to go with your kids, take a pillow with you and try to sleep.

title: A poor follow up to Afterlife
text: "Afterlife" emerged as a heartfelt tribute to the iconic movies of the 1980s, resonating deeply with fans who cherished the era's unique blend of storytelling and character-driven plots. It captured the essence of what made those films memorable-ingenious narrative twists, endearing characters, and a palpable sense of adventure. This movie managed to recapture the old-school charm and whimsy of its predecessors, making it a nostalgic ride for enthusiasts and a delightful discovery for new fans.However, its sequel, "Frozen Empire," starkly contrasts the original's warmth and authenticity. This follow-up feels like a contrived product of corporate strategy rather than a genuine continuation of the storyline that viewers had come to love. The script appears lazily crafted, filled with clichÃ©s and devoid of the earnestness that usually helps characters resonate with the audience. What was once a cast of charming and relatable figures has transformed into a group of characters that are, at best, irritating and, at worst, thoroughly unlikable.The delightful sense of fun, exploration, and mystery that "Afterlife" brought to the screen has been wholly abandoned in "Frozen Empire." Instead, the sequel has pivoted towards integrating typical teen angst and a cruder form of humor that feels misplaced and forced. Such elements do not just undermine the intelligence and emotional depth of the narrative but also alienate viewers who appreciated the more wholesome and engaging tone of the first film."Frozen Empire" also suffers from a severe disconnect with its audience, largely due to its shift in thematic focus. Where the original film celebrated discovery and the joy of overcoming the unknown, the sequel mires itself in superficial conflicts and predictable drama, leaving little room for the genuine development seen in "Afterlife." This not only makes the sequel less compelling but also strips it of the opportunity to build upon the original's legacy in a meaningful way.Moreover, the sequel's attempt to modernize the humor with lowbrow jokes and slapstick scenarios falls flat, contrasting sharply with the clever and often subtle humor that peppered its predecessor. This shift not only feels like a betrayal of the original's spirit but also serves as a barrier for families who expected to share a similarly enjoyable experience with the sequel. Parents hoping to relive the magic of the first movie with their children are likely to find the tone and content of "Frozen Empire" inappropriate and disappointing.It's clear that "Frozen Empire" was intended to capitalize on the success of "Afterlife" without capturing its heart. This approach not only undermines the potential for a genuinely engaging sequel but also demonstrates a lack of respect for the fans and the quality they expect. The charm and engagement that drew audiences to "Afterlife" were replaced with a hollow shell of a sequel, lacking substance and failing to deliver a memorable cinematic experience.While "Afterlife" was a testament to the enduring appeal of 1980s cinema, lovingly crafted to evoke nostalgia and bring joy to both old and new fans, "Frozen Empire" emerges as a stark misstep. It is a sequel that forgets the essence of its origin, choosing instead to tread a path lined with uninspired writing and misplaced priorities. The charm, excitement, and emotional connection that defined the original are conspicuously absent, replaced by a forgettable foray into the overexploited realms of teen drama and misplaced comedy. For fans of the original, "Frozen Empire" is a disappointing departure from everything that made "Afterlife" a beloved revival of 80s cinematic magic.

title: Ghostbusted
text: Ghostbusters : Frozen Empire continues the trend of diminishing returns from Ghostbusters as a franchise. Worse, it's the first time a 'Busters film has fallen into outright bad territory. After the classic 1984 original 1989's sequel was considered a disappointment (although it raked it in at the box office) but still had the charisma of its predecessors iconic cast. The female led reboot in 2016 was fun action comedy but didn't stand up the legendary original. In 2021 they started again with Afterlife, pitching Ghostbusters as Stranger Things in order to move things to a small town and test the water without having to bust the bank. Frozen Empire is a direct sequel to that film (and by extension the first two) but feels like little more than a corporate exercise in mud flinging to see what sticks.We start off with a ghost chase through New York, where Callie Spengler (Carrie Coon), her kids Trevor (Finn Wolfhard) and Phoebe (Mckenna Grace) and Gary Grooberson (Paul Rudd) now live in the iconic firehouse as a family of Ghostbusters. This is a pretty good way of fusing the old and the new and would have been a solid base to build the story from but unfortunately things get messy quickly with a constant assault of characters both old and new. These include but are not limited to; the return of Ghostbuster hating bureaucrat Walter Peck from the original movie, Ray Stantz, Lucky and Podcast from the previous film, Emily Alyn Linda as a possibly friendly ghost, James Acaster as a scientist, Kamail Nanjiani as the mcguffin introducer, OG receptionist Janine and Winston Zedmore as the Nick Fury of the extended Ghostbusters universe the studio desperately want to happen. With so many characters most of them are left with little to do. Nanjiani and Acaster do well with what time they have while pretty much none of the legacy cast feel like they need to be there apart from maybe Winston. As far as one goes, Phoebe Spengler is the main character. This is the sensible choice but while Mckenna Grace puts in a good performance the character spends most of the film whining and moping. Smart teenager who needs to learn to trust and appreciate the people around them is a classic story arc but when Phoebe's response to making a mistake that probably comes with a pretty high body count is to wallow in self pity she is pretty hard to get behind.The lack of focus carries over to the story. The plot involves a mysterious brass ball that contains your standard unimaginable evil but nobody seems too perturbed by it and it's happily left on the back burner while the army of characters carry out their various side quests, such as Trevor trying to catch Slimer (remember him!), Walter Peck (remember him!) still trying to shut the Ghostbusters down thirty years later and Ray encountering the library ghost from the first movie (remember her!) that they apparently never bothered going back to deal with. Maybe they're content to leave well enough alone because they know it contains a particularly lame and stupid looking villain, even in a series not know for great antagonists.It would be uncharitable to say the film is a total right off. The cast are game and mostly do well with what they are given, stuff is constantly happening so even the most impatient kids will struggle to be outright bored and it may tickle the nostalgia bone for some people. Overall though, Frozen Empire aims to simultaneously recreate past glories and usher in a new era but throws too much at both to succeed in either.5 "I understand if you hate me"'s out of 10 potential apocalypses started.

title: Generic
text: I was hoping this movie would surpass the previous one, which was good in my opinion. I saw the poster for this sequel and I immediately imagined New York being invaded by different shaped ghosts. I was expecting the ending to be way more chaotic than what was given to us. Such a big budget film, why not show the audience a few citizens attempting to fight ghosts and failing miserably? This was set in the city of NY where millions live, and the ending was only set in the fire house, with the main characters, and that was it. The beach scene when the ice starts to burst from the ground was definitively not enough. I need it to be more chaotic and diverse. Show a granny smaking a ghost with a purse, a kid catching a ghost with a vacum cleaner, a taxi driving through the sky, etc. In the end, this wasn't worth my time.

title: They should have stuck with the chick movie line. Yet another paying homage to the past film.
text: Just got home from the cinema. This movie was like when will it end. It's far too drawn out with very little plot to support it.Dan Aykroyd was good in it. Evernone else phoned it in but they had little else to do given the plot was so thin.I basically wasted my money on this film but the power was out at home and it was unbearable being without it.They did nothing with slimer or the little marshmellow men. It's full of things that just went nowhere.They barely caught any ghosts. It's really not a funny movie either. The orginal Ghostbusters was funny. This just seems like cashing in on a brand name now.They should have continued the storyline they laid out with the female ghostbusters. That just ended after one movie when they had the sequel already set to go when at the credits they say has anyone heard of Zule?We waited for ages and finally another ghostbusters, and it was afterlife. Sheesh, and now this one double sheesh.

title: perfectly executed!!!
text: Saw this in theaters the day it came out and it was beyond my expectations! Amazing acting and great representation. This is by far the most cinematic movie i've watched ever. The storytelling was wonderful. Absolutely loved it and i can't wait to see it again. Very happy with ghostbusters frozen empire!! Mckenna grace is always an amazing actress and she did not fail to portray her character in the best way possible. This movie is a great modern sequel to the already great original ghostbusters. I also loved the cameos from the original ghostbusters! I'm glad they kept the original comedy of the movies and modernized it for more generations to come. I honestly hope they carry on this legacy and continue to make more sequels! I'll be waiting for the next movie (hopefully)

title: A dull mess -but looks pretty
text: I expected Ghostbusters to be a family film - but this really is for kids.Not much of it makes much sense and nothing really happens - it is a showcase for some good effects.The Ghostbusters are broke - not even the windup windows on their car works - for some reason they still tear up the town busting ghosts, possibly for money but mostly for kicks - I think?The action is slapstick and it is made abundantly clear from the start that nobody is ever going to get hurt, no matter how many cars crash or icicles shoot through the floor everybody is going to be fine.The Ghostbusters are useless at what they do - they have no expertise or skill and really anyone else would be better to take over their business.Then it turns out that the old Ghostbusters are still around and they do have money and aren't quite as useless as the new Ghostbusters.The cast wander around town triggering hat tips to the older films - oh the nostalgia!Then the bad guy is here then someone does a thing and he isn't - the end.This is ok to put on whilst you are doing something more interesting on your phone - James Acaster is surprisingly good and the highlight of the show.The effects are great and it doesn't hang around too long - but even a day latter I am struggling to remember what actually happened - it turns out not much.

title: Predictable, unfunny, undeveloped
text: Let me start by saying I don't like this franchise. Never did. I went to watch this cause Afterlife was actually my favourite Ghostbusters movie so far + the trailer looked solid, so I was hoping to start liking this movies after all... Turns out it was a bad idea.The whole plot of this movie is pretty much as mediocre as it gets. There are many nostalgia baits, relations between characters are terribly undeveloped. At the start it seems like Trevor might have his own arc, something about the way his mother and stepfather don't treat him like an adult, take him seriously or recognize his abmitions, but it quickly gets turned into joke and dropped. Phoebe's arc is extremely basic and all the problems retaled to her get solved too easily. Paul Rudd's character is super cliche and predictable. All the characters from the original movie have no character development, they're here for nostalgia only.And now, we finally get to the biggest problem of this movie, at least in my opinion. I don't think it's about the plot, cause this could have been entertaining enough blockbuster even without many changes in story and characters, but for that it would have to at least have good jokes. And it doesn't. This is one of the most unfunny movies I have seen in a while... How the hell do you do that, when you have Paul Rudd in the cast?! But it's not that much about delivery in this case, these jokes are just terribly written and every character is trying too hard to be funny when they're not. That's the script problem, not the cast problem.So... Predictable, unfunny and undeveloped, as in the title. Many people will probably say it's ok, it's solid, it's entertaining enough, but fortunately my expectations for the cinema are not that low for a long time now.

title: TO HELL WITH THE CRITICS!!!
text: Get ready to bust some chills (and laugh your head off) because Ghostbusters: Frozen Empire is a cinematic ice blast of epic proportions! This film is everything you ever wanted in a sequel - it honours the legacy of the originals, delivers side-splitting laughs, and packs in enough supernatural thrills to keep you glued to your seat. The story is clever and fresh, taking the Ghostbusters crew to a whole new level of ghostly threats. Whether it's facing off against mischievous ice ghosts or unraveling a mystery tied to the afterlife itself, the film keeps you guessing and gasping...............

title: And then play it again and again and again
text: Honestly I didn't want to watch this movie at all, after what they did in "Afterlife" I thought they couldn't go any lower than that but boy was I wrong. There's always space to go down and down and down to the bottom with these neverending franchises nowadays, isn't it?In comparison to Afterlife Frozen empire at least had an original (kind of) idea and a brand new ghost to install fear and I have to admit, at times (like two or three) the movie gave me chills of terror and I reminisced of the good old days when Ghostbusters was branded as horror comedy. For that feeling I'm grateful to this new installment. Unfortunately all the rest felt out of place.How many more times do Bill Murray, Dan Aykroyd and Ernie Hudson have to come back to their roles when all they do on screen is try and hide their boredom, especially Murray who just seems to show up on set for a day or two to shoot his scenes and get the paycheck - he doesn't even move a muscle to portray Venkman and it's just sickening to see such performances which are in abundance here. Why even bother?Paul Rudd obviously had the time of his life in the movie but his character is rather dull, uninspired and looks a lot like his character from the Ant man movies - I know he's a good actor, I just don't know why he doesn't show it here. The rest of the cast is just as bad, I can't even single anybody out because of how unbelievably boring they all are and those dialogues - good golly, who wrote them? There are so many 'likes' in between words one would think they were all improvised. Just add some scientific mumbo jumbo and here you go, you have a script to seven more Ghostbusters movies.I remembered who I liked best - Patton Oswalt, his character was truly original and although is purely expository to the story he gave the most memorable performance, way better than the main cast did.The ghost itself is extremely superficial, ordinary and doesn't do much in the narrative - I can't believe I'm saying this but I miss Vigo from Ghostbusters II who was at least motivated to be a villain throughout the movie and this one (I can't even remember the name) is only there for like fifteen minutes of the whole movie - all the rest is just some family drama blown out of proportions by a teenager who no one supposedly understands, a wannabe father who is as infantile as the said teenager and the bunch of retired old heroes who are present only to serve the movie's title being Ghostbusters. There's literally nothing in this movie that Ghostbusters is all about.Afterlife tried to reboot the franchise by bringing new characters as if to pass the torch from the old ones but Frozen empire does it all over again, only with even less enthusiasm and I can see the writers of the future sequels hopelessly trying to come up with an original idea but failing and doing the same movie over and over again, oh and adding Ray Parker Jr.'s theme song in the end of course - I just don't see myself watching those anymore.

title: Good movie, just needs to be 20mins longer
text: As a huge Ghostbusters fan I felt this movie was good but not great. The cast is great with tons of funny moments. Yet there is so many of them. I felt 20 more mins to this movie and you could have developed story more of the Garaka character. Also gave use more of zeddmore and podcast. A lot of the story felt rush. CGI was ok, wish they stuck more with puppets/person for slimmer and library ghost. Bill Murry and Dan aykroyd were awesome. This felt like a Real Ghostbusters episode which is awesome. I highly recommend give it a shot, with so much recycled stuff, this movie feels new. I do hope they do one more also maybe a better soundtrack.

title: Frustratingly dull
text: I'm honestly gobsmacked as to how a movie franchise with all the potential and ingredients as GHOSTBUSTERS could miss the mark so badly. After a good, fun ten minutes setting up the premise and reintroducing us to the family, the film veers way off course with an hour and a half of absolute bilge before the final showdown.Like many others, I was trying not to let my mind wander halfway through, trying to put into words how and why it was so excruciatingly dull to watch. We were getting characters, scenes, story, exposition, development... but it just all amounted to NOTHING. There was no fun, spectacle or energy whatsoever. By the time it remembered it was a Ghostbusters film we were 20 mins from the end, with zero time for purposeful build up or development and we're hit with a brief, messy finale that made little sense.The acting and dislogue is wishy-washy, the action is practically non-existent, the structure is messy, the story and character development is as see-through as a ghost fart, but worst of all, those callbacks to earlier films. I was hoping they would move on and create a fresh new pallette to compliment the franchise, but no. Again. Like Afterlife (perhaps even worse than Afterlife) there's a tired, desperate sense that we all want to see 'fan favourites' every two minutes. It almost suggests "there's nothing of any substance here, so how about that ghost you loved from the first film". You just can't create something fresh and new, and interesting, when you're so preoccupied by retreading old ground. Yes, we all have the same fondness for the other movies. That's why we go back and watch them. What on earth is the point in wasting an opportunity for further creativity by rehashing what we've already seen a hundred times... especially when it's all out of context as merely 'nods' and detached from having any point whatsoever. Even those stupid marshmallow men. It was done, it was fun. The only emotion they instill now is "oh it's those things again... and again... and again". They serve no purpose anymore other than barring the way for something more interesting. Ditto that for every callback, including the old cast who lack any real purpose or character, or energy, mostly standing around with a figurative foam finger pointing at them screaming LOOK!! IT'S THE OLD GUYS!! They were like traffic cones on a road trip.I have this memory growing up of Christmas lunch with all my extended family. We HAD to eat the 'big meal' but all I wanted, as a 6 year old, was to play with my gifts. Parents would say 'you can play after lunch' and I'd sit, fidgeting and restless, while the adults talked and talked through course after course. Starter, main, dessert, coffee. It was excruciatingly slow and dull. I knew the fun was an arm's length away, but I just had to patiently sit through 2 hours of long, boring chat before I could go have fun. Welcome to Ghostbuster: Frozen Empire.A wasted opportunity, a waste of talent, a waste of time.

title: Wow, what a miss
text: It's the writing silly. It's impossible to make anything of this mash of bad ideas that don't congeal into a cohesive story. It's just one silly slapstick thing after another. And that would be fine it it was funny. But it's never funny! It's also not scary. It's not even amusing. I could hear the audience behind me wanting to laugh but they could barely muster a chuckle.The child actors were fine but not given much in the way of good lines to work with. I actually felt bad for the returning adult actors, few of which needed the paycheck, but there they were. Delivering bad unfunny lines that in my opinion degraded a great original movie that never needed a bad sequel, much less a half a dozen of them. Spare yourself and run from this badly haunted franchise of CGI unfunny, unscary and unentertaining ghost goop.

title: They should try a TV Series
text: What can I say? I'm an old fan who's wishing nothing but the best for my beloved franchise.Still, we need to go further and going all the way down with the wolf.The thing that bothered me the most is the lack of time invested for every characters.New guys are funny, occult moments are awesome and Dan Aykroyd is the Ric Flair of GB, he gonna die bustin.I'm also a Bill Murray fan, I've cheered for his Cubs mid-2010's but Peter Venkman needs to die.Plain and simple.
